description: The infinite Fibonacci word: start with 1, repeatedly apply the morphism 1->12, 2->1, take limit; or, start with S(0)=2, S(1)=1, and for n>1 define S(n)=S(n-1)S(n-2), then the sequence is S(oo).
comments: Or, fixed point of the morphism 1->12, 2->1, starting from a(1) = 2.A Sturmian word, as are all versions of this sequence. This means that if one slides a window of length n along the sequence, one sees exactly n+1 different subwords (see A213975). For a proof, see for example Chap. 2 of Lothaire (2002).The limiting mean of the first n terms is 3 - phi, where phi is the golden ratio (A001622); the limiting variance is 2 - phi. - _Clark Kimberling_, Mar 12 2014The Wikipedia article on L-system Example 1 is "Algae" given by the axiom: A and rules: A -> AB, B -> A. The sequence G(n) = G(n-1)G(n-2) yields this sequence when A -> 1, B -> 2. - _Michael Somos_, Jan 12 2015

formula: Define strings S(0)=2, S(1)=1, S(n)=S(n-1)S(n-2); iterate. Sequence is S(infinity).a(n-1) = n - floor(phi*floor(n/phi)). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Jul 28 2005
example: Over the alphabet {a,b} this is the sequence a, b, a, a, b, a, b, a, a, b, a, a, b, a, b, a, a, b, a, b, a, a, b, a, a, b, a, b, a, a, b, a, a, b, a, b, a, a, b, a, b, a, a, b, a, a, b, a, b, a, a, b, a, b, a, a, b, a, a, b, a, b, a, a, b, a, a, b, a, b, a, a, b, a, b, a, a, b, a, a, b, a, b, a, a, b, a, a, b, a, b, a, a, b, a, b, a, a, b, a, a, b, a, b, a, ...
prog: (Haskell)a003842 n = a003842_list !! na003842_list = tail $ concat fws where   fws = [2] : [1] : (zipWith (++) fws $ tail fws)-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Oct 26 2013
crossrefs: A003849 is another common version of this sequence. A003842 is the {1, 2}-version.
